tee there's two things to bear in mind 1
the egg itself use a hen's egg go for
medium sized to pair up with the timings
we're going to give you and the key is
it has to be fresh also if you do store

temperature it's much easier you can do
that by just submerging it in warm water

secondly the water itself so you want a
big pan with plenty of water good depth
to it and you want to heat that up to a
temperature that we're going to poach in
so bring up the temperature with a lid
it's much quicker what you're looking
for poaching is a few bubbles on the
bottom of the pan that are just breaking
the surface if that's difficult to get
an eye on then you can always take it to
boiling reduce it down to simmering and
then poaching just by turning the heat
off while it is coming up to temperature
if you're not confident a cracking edge
and that risk of breaking the yolk or
getting some shell in then you've got
plenty of time and you can crack some
into ramekins or a small dish bowl
coffee party cup whatever it gives you
more control later on when you're
lowering the eggs into the water this
can be done with just the back of a

crack it into a ramekin alternatively
you could always just crack on the side

eggs in the ramekin one after another
are just going to go into the pan
because they're in the ramekin it's
really simple and you want to leave
those on a very very gentle poach so not
too much movement for 2 or 3 minutes or
a room-temperature egg but more
importantly you can see exactly when
it's done because you can lift out of
the water with a slotted spoon and just
tap on the top you want a soft yolk but
the whites should all be set the
advantage of this method is you can have
multiple eggs in this
same pan at the same time much easier
than the swirling method we can only do
one at a time after two or three minutes
with a slotted spoon you can scoop it
out and the time will vary depending on
your water temperature and the
temperature of your eggs when they went
in but that's what you're looking for a
nice bouncy yolk but the white is all

then onto the plate you're serving

you should have is the perfect runny
